en: Interview with Billy Henriquez, 2021-03-11

In this interview Billy Henriquez, a Honduran immigrant and Gatlinburg resident since 2008, tells the story of his family’s experience with the Chimney Tops wildfires that burned down his home. 
      Billy talks about the shock that ensued after realizing his family no longer had a home to come back to, and the displacement of the Hispanic community that forced many to leave Tennessee. Billy describes 
      the surprising good that came out of the incident which made him and other Hispanic residents feel like they were seen as actual members of the community. This is a representative quote from the interview: 
      "most of the people that helped me, I didn't know them. And that's something I will never forget, that, genuine affection that they had for us, that despite us being foreigners, they acknowledged us as a 
      part, of their community."

Description

In this interview Billy Henriquez, a Honduran immigrant and Gatlinburg resident since 2008, tells the story of his family’s experience with the Chimney Tops wildfires that burned down his home. 
      Billy talks about the shock that ensued after realizing his family no longer had a home to come back to, and the displacement of the Hispanic community that forced many to leave Tennessee. Billy describes 
      the surprising good that came out of the incident which made him and other Hispanic residents feel like they were seen as actual members of the community. This is a representative quote from the interview: 
      "most of the people that helped me, I didn't know them. And that's something I will never forget, that, genuine affection that they had for us, that despite us being foreigners, they acknowledged us as a 
      part, of their community."
Descripción

En esta entrevista Billy Henriquez, inmigrante Hondureño y residente de Gatlinburg desde el 2008, cuenta la historia de la experiencia que tuvo su familia con los incendios forestales de 
      Chimney Tops que quemaron su casa. Billy habla sobre el shock que siguió después de darse cuenta de que su familia ya no tenia un hogar al cual regresar, y el desplazamiento de la comunidad Hispana que 
      obligo a muchos a irse de Tennessee. Billy describe lo bueno que sorprendentemente sucedió debido al incidente que hizo que el y otros residentes Hispanos se sintieran como miembros verdaderos de la 
      comunidad. Esta es una cita representativa de la entrevista: "la mayoría de la gente que me ayudo a mí, no los conocía. Y eso jamás lo voy olvidar pues ese, cariño genuino que tuvieron por
      nosotros, que a pesar de ser extranjeros, nos tomaban como parte, de su comunidad."

Entrevista con Billy Henriquez, 2021-03-11

Interview with Billy Henriquez, 2021-03-11
Preguntas de entrevista
Bueno para empezar vamos a pedir que por favor te introduzcas, diciéndonos tu nombre.
Por cuanto tiempo vivistes en Gatlinburg? Todavia estas viviendo en Gatlinburg o a donde estas ahora?
Y tienes familia en Gatlinburg? Como llegaste a Gatlinburg, de donde eres originalmente?
Okay y nos puedes contar un poco sobre la parte de Gatlinburg en la que vivias verdad antes de que pasaran los incendios?

Y, antes de que empezaran los incendios, tu ya habias escuchado algo sobre, sobre lo que estaba pasando digamos esa semana? Habias escuchado si, si de tus papás o tu dónde estabas cuando escuchastes que posiblemente algo estaba pasando?
Y, cuando dices verdad que, que habías escuchado verdad que sí que había humo. Habías escuchado algún reporte sobre esto en las noticias o, o la ciudad? Algun mensaje o, o no?
Y en qué momento fue cuando te empezastes a preocupar por lo que estaba pasando, o por lo que podía pasar posiblemente?
Y, cuando tus papas evacuaron verdad. Cómo fue la experiencia verdad después de la de la evacuación. Mientras ellos estaban esperando que, los dejaran entrar a la ciudad?

Y durante este tiempo verdad, de la evacuación y estaban esperando, de qué manera verdad, te, te estabas manteniendo en contacto con tu familia? Fue puramente redes sociales o, o como verdad mantuviste contacto?

Y nos puedes describir como fue regresar a Gatlinburg después de los incendios? Y, y digamos ver a, ver la casa verdad, ver a los vecinos por primera vez. Digamos regresar a, a tratar de, de integrarse otra vez en la ciudad?

Y, aunque no estabas verdad en, en Gatlinburg mientras eso estaba pasando verdad los incendios. Como evaluarías tú, los esfuerzos de rescate, que trataron de ayudar o digamos, los primeros auxilios, los oficiales de la ciudad, FEMA? Piensas que, hicieron un buen trabajo, hubieron, habrían hecho mas o, como te sientes?
Y emocionalmente, cómo te impactó a ti y a tu familia, los incendios verdad y todo lo que pasó?

Y, digamos, aunque tu verdad estabas estudiando en la Universidad, y trabajando un trabajo que estaba Knoxville. Cómo crees que, afectaron los incendios posiblemente a ti, a tu familia, económicamente?

Entiendo, y desde tu punto de vista, cómo influyeron los los incendios verdad, las relaciones comunitarias, en Gatlinburg? Se que ya mencionaste verdad un poco de eso pero, digamos, qué tipo de, de impacto tuvo este incidente verdad en las relaciones comunitarias y también específicamente, en la comunidad Hispana?
Dirías que, la ayuda que, que recibieron verdad y que, que la gente estaba dando, fue lo más sorprendente, lo más sorprendente, de lo que pasó verdad, del incidente fue la ayuda?
Y desde que pasó eso, verdad, sabes si, si tu familia verdad ha hecho algún plan o, o ha pensado verdad, si algo similar vuelve a pasar, verdad que van a hacer, o se sienten más preparados ahora?

Y también verdad los incendios tuvieron un impacto grave en la comunidad Hispana. Y ahora este último año verdad, hemos estando lidiando con la pandemia de Covid-19. Nos puedes comentar un poco verdad en, como la pandemia te ha afectado a ti a tu familia, a la comunidad.

Y mencionaste verdad, anteriormente que la parte en la que vivían antes, verdad la casa que se quemo, habian bastantes Hondureños viviendo ahi. Puedes hablar un poco de, de cómo afectó verdad los incendios a, a la vivienda en Gatlinburg? Y el trabajo digamos tal vez específicamente para, para la comunidad Hispana verdad que se sabe que normalmente, tienen verdad su propio, su propio lugar en Gatlinburg. Cómo afectó verdad los incendios a, a la vivienda?

En todo verdad lo que pasó durante los incendios después de los incendios. Hay alguna memoria o alguna historia, que en tu cabeza verdad siempre, siempre está ahí o siempre, piensas verdad en esa historia? Algo que, que nunca vas a poder olvidar. Si sea tu historia o la de alguien más o, hay alguna memoria?
Interview Questions
Well to begin, we're going to ask that you please introduce yourself, by telling us your name.
How long did you live in Gatlinburg? Are you still living in Gatlinburg or where are you now?
And do you have family in Gatlinburg? How did you arrive to Gatlinburg, where are you originally from?
Okay and can you tell us a little about the part of Gatlinburg you lived in before the fires happened?

And, before the fires began, had you already heard something about, about what was going on that week? Had you heard from, from your parents or where were you when you heard that there was something possibly going on?
And, when you say that, that you had heard that there was smoke. Had you heard a report about this on the news or, or the city? Some sort of message or, or no?
And what was the moment that you started to worry about what was going on, or what could possibly happen?
And, when your parents evacuated. What was the experience like after the evacuation. While they were waiting to be, allowed back into the city?

And during this time of the, of the evacuation and you all waiting, in what ways were you, were you keeping in touch with your family? Was it purely through social networks or, or how did you maintain contact?
And can you describe to us what it was like to return to Gatlinburg after the fires? And, and see the house, see the neighbors for the first time. Going back to try and integrate into the city again?

And, even though you weren't in, in Gatlinburg while the fires were happening. How would you evaluate the rescue efforts, that tried to help or let's say the, first aid, the city ​​officials, FEMA? Do you think they, did a good job, should they have done more or, how do you feel?
And emotionally, how did this impact you and your family, the fires and everything that happened?
And, even though you were studying at the University, and working a job that was in Knoxville. How do you think the fires possibly affected you, your family, financially?

I understand, and from your point of view, how did the fires influence, the community relations, in Gatlinburg? I know you already mentioned a little bit about that but, what kind of, impact did this incident have on community relations and also specifically, on the Hispanic community?
Would you say that, the help that, was received and that people were giving, was the most surprising, the most surprising, thing that came from the incident was the help?

And since this happened, do you know if, if your family has made some sort of plan or, or has thought about, if something similar happens again, what they are going to do, or do they feel more prepared now?

And the fires also had a serious impact on the Hispanic community. And now this past year we have been dealing with the Covid-19 pandemic. Can you tell us a little about how the pandemic has affected you, your family, the community?

And earlier you mentioned that the area in which, in which you all lived before, the house that burned down, there were a lot of Hondurans living there. Can you speak a little about how, how the fires affected the, the housing in Gatlinburg? And jobs maybe specifically for the, the Hispanic community which is known to usually have, they have their own, their own area in Gatlinburg. How did the fires affect housing?

Amongst all that happened during the fires, after the fires. Is there any memory or story, that in your head is always, always there or you always think about that specific story? Something that, that you will never be able to forget. Whether it's your story or someone else's or, any memory?

      Billy talks about the shock that ensued after realizing his family no longer had a home to come back to, and the displacement of the Hispanic community that forced many to leave Tennessee. Billy describes
